subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. Today I'd
like to share with you my anticipation
and excitement about a meeting that's
scheduled to take place tomorrow about a
person that I haven't seen in about 45 years.
Someone I once interviewed back in the
days when I was doing radio interviews
on KPFA FM Radio in Berkeley, the Pacifica
listener sponsored radio station. Early
on in my career, at the time she
introduced herself to me as Timothy
Leary's wife, Joanna Leary. Now, we know
she really wasn't formally married.
Her full correct name is Joanna
Harcourt-Smith. About 4-5 years
ago she authored a book called Tripping
the Bardo with Timothy Leary. It
describes the life that she had together
for about 3 or 4 very crucial
years. She met Leary in Switzerland after
he had already escaped from prison in
the United States and was being sought
by President Nixon and the DEA. They were
eager to re-arrest him and to put him back
into jail. It was a great embarrassment
to them that he had managed to escape
from prison.
She was with him for an intense
prior of about seven weeks during which
time they took LSD, I think, every
day plus a wide variety of other
substances. Then [they] flew to Afghanistan
where he was captured again by US drug
enforcement agents, flown back to the
United States, put into prison and she
worked very hard for years to secure his
release. Finally, the only way he was
able to free himself from the situation
he was in, in the confines of the
federal government, was to actually
become an informant, to
work with the DEA. She writes about
this in her book. It is very well written,
very eloquent. She really has a flair for
writing, Tripping the Bardo with Timothy
Leary. I recommend the book if you're
interested in that period. Perhaps
I'll have her right here in this room in
this studio tomorrow.
Subsequently, she has created a podcast
called Future Primitive. I think she
has a big focus on ecology, a big focus
on spirituality and Buddhism, she's a
practicing Buddhist now, and higher
consciousness. She's been sober for
decades. In her novel - it's not a
novel, it's a true book, it reads like a
novel but it is a memoir - in it
she describes a terrible time,
the craziness of the1970s. It really was
the 1970s although we're talking about, I
would say, the early 70s which was really,
to my way of thinking, an extension of
the 1960s. Her intimacy and closeness
with Timothy Leary, she's actually
credited as co-author with him of some
of his books. So, we might talk about
her current interests. We might talk
about her book. It will be very interesting
to be with a person I haven't seen in 45
years. I imagine she may invite me to
be interviewed on her podcast. I learned
that she was located nearby in Santa Fe
because some weeks ago I interviewed
Marjorie Woollacott, many of you no doubt
have seen some of the Marjorie Woollacott
interviews and it turns out that after
Marjorie came here she drove up to Santa
Fe to be interviewed by Joanna
and mentioned that she had been with me.
Joanna said, "Oh my gosh, I remember him
from so long ago." So now, we are
reconnecting. I can tell you that when I
interviewed her last
she came to make an announcement, and did
on the radio for all of our listeners at
the time that she and Timothy Leary were
going to go on a hunger strike until he
gets released from prison, because she
felt he was being held there on
trumped up charges, which I think was
probably true to a certain extent. In any
case, they didn't have the hunger strike
and I remember thinking to myself at the
time, as interesting as this person was
and as fascinated as I have always been
with Timothy Leary, it was really flaky
to make a public announcement that
you're going on a hunger strike without
any real preparation or ability to
follow through. But that was over four
decades ago and I have every reason to
think that she has matured enormously
since that time. It will be
interesting to reflect with her about
that period in our lives. Now, you
may be asking yourself, what's in it for
you? Why are you bothering
to watch me prattle on about Joanna Harcourt-
Smith and the time I met her
in 1973. Well, think about it. Are there
people in your life that you haven't
seen for a very, very long time? People
with whom you had a significant
interaction and then you went your
separate ways?
Do you wonder sometimes what has become
of them? Have you moved in different
directions? Have they evolved on their
own path as you have on yours?
Here's another question for those of you
who are old enough to remember the 1970s
and the 1960s. What was the significance
of that era? It was so important to
people of my generation, coming of age.
In the year 1970 I was 24 years old.
I was becoming an adult. The things that
were current in the air: the talk of
revolution, the anti-war movement, the use
of psychedelic drugs, the idea of a
spiritual revelation, the booming
interest in mysticism in our culture, the
craziness, the use of drugs, the other
habits people were into at that
time, the sexual revolution that was
going on, the social experimentation that
was going on. Was it all for naught? Or
were there some things of value in that
era? Things we would all do well to
pay more attention to remind
ourselves about. Have we forgotten some
of the best aspects of that time? Or have
we forgotten some of the worst? It
certainly was a time of enormous promise
and enormous disappointment. It's worth
reflecting on. I hope to have a
chance to do that here, right here in
this room tomorrow with Joanna Harcourt-
Smith. If that happens as planned
I'll be sharing it with you. In the
meantime this monologue is
a little introduction to what may be
available in the future. I can't say for
sure because I have to feel out her
interests and her mood to know what we
will be talking about on camera, if
anything. But it will be an interesting
encounter, presuming that she shows up as
scheduled. I'm looking forward to it
and I expect to have more to share with you.
Thank you for being with me.
